repnme.cdata!: Guinea - The Education For All Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education For All Project for Guinea
            was moderately unsatisfactory with a substantial risk to
            development outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrowers
            performance in the project was moderately unsatisfactory.
            Key changes made to the project through the following four
            restructurings include: revision of results framework to
            focus on primary education, scaling up of activities for
            primary education, additional financing revision of PDO and
            some revision of the results framework to align with project
            activities, and an extension of the closing date by six
            months. The following six lessons were learned from this
            project: (1) Strategic sequencing is critical in ensuring
            objectives can be achieved. Although many of the projects
            objectives have been achieved, a number of them might have
            been achieved in a timelier and more efficient manner if
            they had been more carefully selected and appropriately
            sequenced. (2) Student learning achievement levels which
            have been evaluated regularly by national structures, often
            in collaboration with regional institutions or specific
            programs can be used to inform policy. (3) One of the
            important building blocks for undertaking difficult reforms
            (e.g., related to human resources, budgeting, etc.) is the
            involvement of institutional staff intimately familiar with
            the issues rather than relying on a parallel project unit.
            (4) The Banks swift engagement in periods following a
            crisis can bring important dividends. (5) While consultancy
            services and technical assistance (TA) supported under the
            project had a positive impact on achievement of outcomes,
            the lack of skills transfer to staff from government
            institutions could inhibit the development of long-term
            capacity within the institutions. (6) In instances where a
            projects life extends far beyond what was originally
            envisaged, in-depth and periodic evaluations may provide the
            necessary data to effectively evaluate the projects
            progress towards achievement of the PDO as well as to
            undertake measures which further increase the likelihood
            that the project will achieve its intended development goals.

15597942.majtheme: Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Additional Financing for the
            Education for All Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Additional
            Financing for the Education for All (EFA) Project is to
            assist the recipient in its efforts to improve the
            conditions for teaching and learning in its territory,
            through 1) expanded access to education, 2) enhanced quality
            of learning, and 3) strengthened capacity for decentralized
            management of the sector. The changes are: a) revision of
            the project development objective to take account of the
            revised priorities in the education sector; b) revision of
            component three to be aligned with the revised objective and
            including the activities to be financed under the additional
            financing; c) revision of component one to include the
            maintenance costs of the lower secondary schools (colleges);
            d) revision of cost estimates per component; e) revision of
            the implementation arrangement in alignment with those from
            the EFA Fast Track Initiative (FTI) Catalytic Fund (CF); and
            f) reallocation of grant proceeds. The restructuring will
            ensure the positive impact of new investments in the sector,
            including the US$40 million grant from the EFA FTI CF. The
            overall results framework will be clarified and revised for
            both the credit and the additional financing.
